Question: Java Postfix Expression Evaluator: :I really need help with my post-fix expression calculator. I don't really know what's wrong with the code that I've written, however when I run the program, it just prints whatever number is on the top. For example, if I input "7 2 +", the output is 2. If I input "2 7 +", the output is 7. Could somebody please point me in the right direction on how to fix this? I think (not sure) that the problem is that my program is not able to properly detect the operands "+" and "*". However, I can't tell why. File #1:    import java.io.*;import java.util.*;public class ProblemTwo {    public static void main(String[] args) {        Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);        System.out.println("Enter a post value expression: ");        String input = scan.nextLine();        StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(input);        Stack hello = new Stack(st.countTokens());        for (int i = 0; i <= st.countTokens(); i++) {            String inputToken = st.nextToken();            if (inputToken.trim().contains("+")) {                int sum = Integer.parseInt(hello.pop() + Integer.parseInt(hello.pop()));                System.out.println(sum);                hello.push(Integer.toString(sum));            }            else if (inputToken.trim().contains("*")){                int product = Integer.parseInt(hello.pop()) * Integer.parseInt(hello.pop());                hello.push(Integer.toString(product));            }            else {                hello.push(inputToken);            }        }        System.out.println(hello.pop());    }}File #2: public class Stack {        private String[] stackArray;        private int arraySize;        private int top;        public Stack(int capacity) {            arraySize = capacity;            stackArray = new String[arraySize];            top = -1;        }        public void push(String i) {            stackArray[++top] = i;        }        public String pop() {            return stackArray[top--];        }        public boolean isEmpty() {            return top == -1;        }        public boolean isFull() {            return top == arraySize - 1;        }    }
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.

Question: Java Postfix Expression Evaluator: :I really need help with my post-fix expression calculator. I don't really know what's wrong with the code that I've written, however when I run the program, it just prints whatever number is on the top. For example, if I input "7 2 +", the output is 2. If I input "2 7 +", the output is 7. Could somebody please point me in the right direction on how to fix this? I think (not sure) that the problem is that my program is not able to properly detect the operands "+" and "*". However, I can't tell why. File #1:    import java.io.*;import java.util.*;public class ProblemTwo {    public static void main(String[] args) {        Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);        System.out.println("Enter a post value expression: ");        String input = scan.nextLine();        StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(input);        Stack hello = new Stack(st.countTokens());        for (int i = 0; i <= st.countTokens(); i++) {            String inputToken = st.nextToken();            if (inputToken.trim().contains("+")) {                int sum = Integer.parseInt(hello.pop() + Integer.parseInt(hello.pop()));                System.out.println(sum);                hello.push(Integer.toString(sum));            }            else if (inputToken.trim().contains("*")){                int product = Integer.parseInt(hello.pop()) * Integer.parseInt(hello.pop());                hello.push(Integer.toString(product));            }            else {                hello.push(inputToken);            }        }        System.out.println(hello.pop());    }}File #2: public class Stack {        private String[] stackArray;        private int arraySize;        private int top;        public Stack(int capacity) {            arraySize = capacity;            stackArray = new String[arraySize];            top = -1;        }        public void push(String i) {            stackArray[++top] = i;        }        public String pop() {            return stackArray[top--];        }        public boolean isEmpty() {            return top == -1;        }        public boolean isFull() {            return top == arraySize - 1;        }    }
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer: The problem with your code is that you are not correctly handling the operands "+" and "*". In your code, you are trying to perform arithmetic operations on the top two elements of the stack, but you are not storing the result back in the stack. 

Here is the corrected code:

```java
import java.io.*;
import java.util.*;

public class ProblemTwo {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);
        System.out.println("Enter a post value expression: ");
        String input = scan.nextLine();
        StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(input);
        Stack hello = new Stack(st.countTokens());
        while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
            String inputToken = st.nextToken();
            if (inputToken.equals("+")) {
                int num2 = Integer.parseInt(hello.pop());
                int num1 = Integer.parseInt(hello.pop());
                int sum = num1 + num2;
                hello.push(Integer.toString(sum));
            } else if (inputToken.equals("*")) {
                int num2 = Integer.parseInt(hello.pop());
                int num1 = Integer.parseInt(hello.pop());
                int product = num1 * num2;
                hello.push(Integer.toString(product));
            } else {
                hello.push(inputToken);
            }
        }
        System.out.println(hello.pop());
    }
}

public class Stack {
    private String[] stackArray;
    private int arraySize;
    private int top;

    public Stack(int capacity) {
        arraySize = capacity;
        stackArray = new String[arraySize];
        top = -1;
    }

    public void push(String i) {
        stackArray[++top] = i;
    }

    public String pop() {
        return stackArray[top--];
    }

    public boolean isEmpty() {
        return top == -1;
    }

    public boolean isFull() {
        return top == arraySize - 1;
    }
}
```

This code will correctly evaluate postfix expressions. It uses a stack to store operands and performs the appropriate arithmetic operation when it encounters an operator. The result of the operation is then pushed back onto the stack. The final result is the top element of the stack.

Please note that this code assumes that the input expression is correctly formatted and does not handle any error checking or validation. You may want to add additional code to handle invalid input or edge cases.
